repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6750

In `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` handle `bytes`-like objects (such as `const char[:]`) by adding support for [the Python Buffer Protocol]( https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/buffer.html ).

comment_data.body:
Seeing some compile error suggesting `Py_buffer` is unavailable in some builds. Guessing this is related to Python Limited API support. To fix that looks like we want something like this

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/bf59121ba5c9f79b4bbfeab05407c15e07e4cb15/Cython/Utility/StringTools.c#L767-L799

Looking at that code, it doesn't adapt that well to here. The idea of `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` is to get a pointer to underlying memory in the object. However the other code creates a temporary `bytes` object, whose memory it uses within the lifespan of that temporary. Given `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` has no real way to keep temporary objects (like `bytes`) alive, passing pointers to said temporary objects back to users is UB. So we can't use that

Maybe there are some other options I'm overlooking. Though a simple solution would just be to error in the Python Limited API case

> keep temporary objects (like `bytes`) alive

This also applies to buffers, though. The buffer view is only guaranteed to be usable until we call `PyBuffer_Release()`. After that, the buffer is allowed to become unavailable and should not be used any more.

Buffers need to be handled in place, where and as long as they are used.

Yep agreed, which we do in this code currently

Am more meaning I don't see a good fallback for the Limited API on Python pre-3.11. Though could just be missing alternatives

If you have suggestions, please let me know 🙂

Or actually does your comment ( https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6750#issuecomment-2744947269 ) mean we should consider moving this code from `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` to the `string.from_py` functions?

Because then we could use the same fallback mechanism

> consider moving this code from `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` to the `string.from_py` functions

Yes. It's safe to do there but not in `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize`.

The best general solution is probably `https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/arg.html#c.PyArg_ParseTuple` with `z#`,

If you look at the implementation of that it allows anything that implements the buffer protocol but doesn't specifically have `bf_releasebuffer` (which implies that the buffer is good so long as the object exists). That's "borrowed" but no worse than what we have for bytes.

That's a good suggestion!

Haven't used the `PyArg_*Parse*` functions much before

Tried rewriting this below

Used [`PyArg_Parse`]( https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/arg.html#c.PyArg_Parse ) as it looks like that can take a single value

Also from [the "strings and buffers" section]( https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/arg.html#strings-and-buffers ) used `y#` as it looks like it is limited to `bytes`-like objects where a pointer and size can be returned

Edit: If we wanted to handle unicode `str`s as well, we could use `s#`. If we wanted to handle `None` too, we could use `z#`. Though in the latter case maybe we are better off to define behavior for `None` (if is it important)
Should add was able to test this out locally and it worked ok

Looks like the syntax of the traceback message changes to look more like this

Are we ok with that? If so, can push similar changes to the test suite

Alternatively we can change the error messaging in the function
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@ def test_conversion(py_obj):
     True
     >>> test_conversion(123)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
     Traceback (most recent call last):
-    TypeError: expected ..., int found
+    TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'int'

comment_data.body:
I was generally unimpressed by the performance of the `PyArg_*()` functions and tend to avoid them if possible. Not sure if it makes a difference here, given that the most important cases are already handled up-front and we end up asking the owner to fill our buffer struct etc. These things usually tend to harm smaller data buffers more than larger ones.

If it turns out to be a visible factor, we could try to inline the relevant code for `y#` specifically. Cython has helper macros to look up slots in both the normal and Limited C-API.
We try to avoid also error message changes if it's somewhat reasonable, but usually follow what CPython outputs (at the Python level).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@ def test_conversion(py_obj):
     True
     >>> test_conversion(123)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
     Traceback (most recent call last):
-    TypeError: expected ..., int found
+    TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'int'

comment_data.body: The only thing there is hat you can't use `PyType_GetSlot` to "backdate" support in the Limited API so I think `PyArg_Parse` may be the only option there. Agree with backdating it elsewhere.

The change in the error message is a result of the fact that the `else` case was handling `bytes` objects. Now it is handling any `bytes`-like object

This matches what one would get from `memoryview`. For example

```python
In [1]: memoryview(1)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In[1], line 1
----> 1 memoryview(1)

TypeError: memoryview: a bytes-like object is required, not 'int'
```

Not sure what the equivalent of `PyBytes_AsStringAndSize` would have been in Python

<hr>

If we still want the same error message as before, probably the simplest option is to move the `bytes` handling case back into the `else`. So we would check for a non-`bytes` object for our new case in `else if`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@ def test_conversion(py_obj):
     True
     >>> test_conversion(123)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
     Traceback (most recent call last):
-    TypeError: expected ..., int found
+    TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'int'

comment_data.body:
Tried the following approaches

```cython
from cpython.getargs cimport PyArg_Parse
from cpython.buffer cimport (
    PyBUF_SIMPLE, Py_buffer,
    PyObject_GetBuffer, PyBuffer_Release,
)


cpdef noop_to_c_string(b):
    pass


cpdef pybuf_to_c_string(b):
    cdef Py_buffer pb
    cdef const char* s
    cdef Py_ssize_t n
    try:
        PyObject_GetBuffer(b, &pb, PyBUF_SIMPLE)
        s = <const char*>pb.buf
        n = pb.len
    finally:
        PyBuffer_Release(&pb)


cpdef pyarg_to_c_string(b):
    cdef const char* s
    cdef Py_ssize_t n
    PyArg_Parse(b, "y#", &s, &n)
```

Then used the string `b"abc"` to get the following results

```python
%timeit noop_to_c_string(b)
15.3 ns ± 0.0764 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 100,000,000 loops each)

%timeit pybuf_to_c_string(b)
18.7 ns ± 0.259 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 100,000,000 loops each)

%timeit pyarg_to_c_string(b)
31.3 ns ± 0.31 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10,000,000 loops each)
```

So agree it is slower to use `PyArg_Parse` and is probably best saved as a fallback for the limited API on Python pre-3.11

As `PyObject_GetBuffer`, is already calling the slot functions itself and a Python interpreter could be compiled with build time optimizations, likely that is about as fast as gets

Can add a compile time branch in this `else` to capture these two cases

Actually another option would be to use [the old-style buffer protocol]( https://docs.python.org/3.12/c-api/objbuffer.html#old-buffer-protocol ). This is part of the stable API and was around until Python 3.12

If we did this we could call [`PyObject_AsCharBuffer`]( https://docs.python.org/3.12/c-api/objbuffer.html#c.PyObject_AsCharBuffer ) like so

```suggestion
        int r = PyObject_AsCharBuffer(o, &result, &length);
```

Under-the-hood [it just uses the new buffer protocol]( https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/fdb81425a9ad683f8c24bf5cbedc9b96baf00cd2/Objects/abstract.c#L318-L334 )

AFAICT it doesn't check whether releasing the buffer is required. It just always releases the buffer

I think the `expected x, y found` message is more suitable for one concrete expected type. It doesn't fit if multiple types are acceptable. The `bytes-like object` message seems better adapted to that case. Feel free to change it.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@ def test_conversion(py_obj):
     True
     >>> test_conversion(123)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
     Traceback (most recent call last):
-    TypeError: expected ..., int found
+    TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'int'

comment_data.body:
> AFAICT it doesn't check whether releasing the buffer is required. It just always releases the buffer

But that doesn't make it any better than what the current master branch does, right?
Sorry which behavior in `master` are you referring to? An example would help contextualize it

For now have added `Py_buffer` approach for most cases (non-Limited API on any Python version or Python 3.11+ w/Limited API). So that ensures the bulk of cases get the more performant approach. Also added a check that the slot `bf_releasebuffer` is `NULL` and raised an error if not

For all other cases (so Limited API on 3.8, 3.9 or 3.10), we fallback to `PyArg_Parse`. It is slower, but it still provides the new behavior in those cases. Should add [the `PyArg_Parse` case does check that the buffer does not need to be released]( https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/8a00c9a4d2ce9d373b13f8f0a2265a65f4523293/Python/getargs.c#L1245-L1250 )

Included a custom error at the end. Updated any failing case to `goto` it

All successful cases `return` avoiding it entirely
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -20,7 +20,7 @@ def test_conversion(py_obj):
     True
     >>> test_conversion(123)  # doctest: +ELLIPSIS
     Traceback (most recent call last):
-    TypeError: expected ..., int found
+    TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'int'

comment_data.body:
Have changed the logic to use `Py_buffer` where possible

Now `PyArg_Parse` is used as fallback

Have added this guard to only use the Python Buffer Protocol in either non-Limited API builds or Limited API builds on Python 3.11+. In those cases this path should be ok

Also added an explicit check that the Python Buffer Protocol does work on this object. This check can only be done under the conditions laid out previously (as the slots checked are in [the Limited API beginning with Python 3.11]( https://docs.python.org/3.13/c-api/type.html#c.PyType_Slot.slot )). However this does help us pick out any cases where the object doesn't support the Python Buffer Protocol or it does, but depends on releasing the buffer after

Please let me know if there are other cases we should check for or if this needs tweaking

We still release the buffer as it does some cleanup of the buffer object itself (namely [decref-ing the associated object]( https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/52b5eb95b770fa00ebbd449ba40cab4a0e7c7df7/Objects/abstract.c#L817-L818 ))

Thought it better to call the standard function here instead of bypassing it by doing our own version of this cleanup
Added a generic error for all cases to use here. Please let me know what you think about this and if there are things we want to improve about it

Tried to add a warning in relation to issue: https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/6760

Since we are providing an alternative path, which would avoid that bug here, it makes sense to encourage its use

Please let me know what you think

At first read, this seems to suggest using `::1` specifically to solve this problem, but that has nothing to do with it.
```suggestion
        int r = PyErr_WarnEx(
            PyExc_RuntimeWarning,
            "Cython: Pointer taken from resizable `bytearray` object. "
            "To restrict resizing instead use a memory view, e.g. `unsigned char[::1]`.",
```
If you want this to work in the Limited API, you need to use `__Pyx_PyType_GetSlot()`.

> > consider moving this code from `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` to the `string.from_py` functions
> 
> Yes.

I think this got lost. It's still better to use the buffer protocol directly in places where we need the data within a well-defined scope. That's still more general than letting `__Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize` exclude types that require buffer releasing.
I think you probably need to request both slot functions separately, not the buffer struct slot.

title: [WIP] Handle `bytes`-like objects in C-string conversion
